title: Apple Johnnyseed
body:
It’s lonely in his forest. All the trees are moaning, and none of us have leaves.

Oh God - It’s him - It’s Apple Johnnyseed. He’s come for me. Please listen to my story and help me if you can.

I was running late for work this morning, so I didn’t have time to cook breakfast of fix a lunch. I bike to work, because its just as fast once you account for traffic.

Plus, I need the exercise. By the time I was halfway to my job, I was starving. Luckily, my route today took me past a fruit stand.

A grizzled old hag sat on a stool behind the counter, reading a book. She hardly looked up when I skidded to a stop in front of her store to buy some fruit. I was in a hurry, but I tried to be friendly anyway.

“Hi there! What are you reading?” I picked up a piece of fruit and handed her some cash.

“Oh, just some old folk tale. Probably wouldn’t interest someone like you.”

She closed the book and placed it on the counter. It looked ancient, bound in tattered leather. On the cover – which seemed barely adhered to the pages – was a strange title.

Apple Johnnyseed

“Oh! Is it about Johnny Appleseed?”

“Does it say Johnny Appleseed?”

“Well… no, but who in the world is Apple Johnnyseed?”

“Why don’t you take it with you and find out. No charge.” She slid the book over to me with a grin.

I took the book without much thought and pedaled the rest of the way to my workplace as fast as I could, passing several spindly, sickly-looking trees on the way.

The city must have planted them recently, because I’d never noticed them before. It’s springtime, so all the other trees are blooming, but none of these had a single leaf. Nice to see the government putting my tax dollars to good use.

I arrived just seconds before 8 o’clock, so I didn’t even have time to enjoy the fruit I’d purchased. I was swamped at work, so I didn’t really think again about the book until it was time for my lunch break.

When I got off, I walked a couple of blocks to the city park, excited to finally have time to eat my fruit. I found a nice, solitary park bench on which to eat my lunch, passing a few more of those pale, thin trees on my walk over.

They really were odd. Their branches creaked and groaned as I walked past, seeming to bend and wave in the wind, almost like they were trying to get my attention.

As I munched on my fruit, I had my phone in my hand, checking Reddit. But, I couldn’t find anything interesting, so I decided to read the old, wormy book to pass the time.

This is what it said.

Listen dear reader and pay me some heed.

Don’t cross mean old Apple Johnnyseed.

He’s a terrible planter. A mean old crook.

He beat me blue ‘til I wrote him this book.

He towered above me and gave me a slap.

Threatened to boil me alive in his tin pot cap.

His terrible scars were a terrible fright.

His deep voice dictated the words I now write.

”In his youth, Apple Johnnyseed wasn’t so bad,

‘til he got beaten blue at the hands of his dad.

The awful old man tied his little boy up,

And bruised him and broke him with apples he chucked.”

”But Apple Johnnyseed didn’t cry, and he didn’t pout.

He just took his lumps ‘til the apples ran out.

Then he waited ‘til nighttime when daddy got drunk,

Then he took a big knife. Then he cut off dad's junk.”

”His mean daddy screamed as he slowly bled out,

And he got big red stains on mama’s nice couch.

His body, it rotted and ran out of juice,

But I saved his two balls, and I put them to use.

I planted his stuff in the black earth out back.

I planted his nuts, and I planted his sack.

I watered and tended them so tender-ly.

And soon I had grown my first Johnnyseed tree.”

“It pleased me so much. I just had to have more.

And since then I’ve grown least three dozen score.

They moan, and they groan, but they don’t bear no fruit.

NO MORE APPLES TO GET FUCKING CHUCKED BY THAT BRUTE.”

When his story gets read, he’s always nearby.

With his pot on his head, and his knife hand held high.

So all you apple-loving bastards beware,

Lest you be caught up in Johnyseed’s snare.

If you read his tale with an apple in hand,

He’ll boil your bits, and he’ll sow the land.

So avoid the curs’d fruit and leave them all be,

Or you might just wind up as a Johnnyseed tree.

THE END

How do people come up with this stuff?! I mean, come onnnn. Reading a book “with an apple in hand” curses you to be castrated and turned into a “Johnnyseed tree?”

Oh nooooo! I’m scaaaared! Thank God I’d bought a banana at the fruit stand this morning.

What? You thought it was an apple I bought earlier? No way. Potassium all day, baby. You really thought I was going to get butchered by some crazed fruit maniac?

“Apple Johnnyseed.” What a joke. I laughed when I thought of how silly it was to be afraid of a children’s tale like that. Someone had probably just written that lame story to make fun of the city’s attempt at growing these pitiful, creepy looking trees.

Then I heard another voice laughing behind me, and an impossibly large shadow fell over me. I was too afraid to turn around, but when I heard him sharpening his knife, I knew Apple Johnnyseed had come for me.

That’s when I realized my mistake.

I’d read the story with my iPhone in my hand.

There it was… the Apple logo, shining clear as day. I’m sorry, fellow iPhone users. He gave me time to write to you, so I could have you as companions forever.

It’s lonely in his forest. All the trees are moaning, and none of us have leaves.

Deesco5
author: Deesco5
